What is it?

  • Client side MV(C) framework
  • Made of separate modules
  • Started in 2009 with first stable version in June 2012

Projects built with AngularJS

  • Youtube App on PS3
  • Vevo
  • MSNBC.com
  • Trailers for Netflix
  • Sky Store

Capabilities

  • Can be used as a jQuery replacement
  • Integrated into any website or web app
  • Single Page Applications (SPA)
  • Hybrid Apps (Cordova, PhoneGap)
but, before diving into
AngularJS
make sure you’re confident with

JavaScript

“When coding Angular,
you’re coding JavaScript.

It’s essential to understand its quirks when developing large scale applications”

so,

JavaScript

Why is it important?

“It’s everywhere,
and it keeps on growing.”
Even this presentation has JavaScript all over.

The Good

  • Easy to learn
  • Interpreted Language (no need to compile)
  • It’s a Prototype-Based Language
  • It’s Object Oriented
  • It’s Loosely Typed
  • Tools are getting better
  • Very fast and powerful
  • Easily extensible (jQuery, BackboneJS, EmberJS, AngularJS, and more)
  • Not just for front-end

The Bad

  • Implied Globals
  • Understanding how this works
  • Understanding how hoisting works
  • Understanding how scoping works
  • Automatic semicolon insertion (ASI)
  • Types are misleading. Type of null is "object"?
  • and more

References

  • JavaScript the right way
  • JavaScript the Good Parts by Douglas Crockford
  • Things I wish I knew much earlier [about JavaScript]
  • JavaScript Scoping and Hoisting
  • Introduction to Object Oriented JavaScript
  • An interesting read: JavaScript, the George Clooney of Programming Languages
one final important prerequisite

Asynchronous Programming

“…mastering asynchronous programing in JavaScript is a must for any serious HTML5 application developer…”


@jeremychone — HTML 5 Rocks

Promises & Deferreds

a concept that has been around since 1976

http://en.wiki…

What are these?

  • A Promise is an object that is yet to have its value assigned
  • A Deferred is an object that has work, which is not yet finished.

In JavaScript, these allow for asynchronous code to be executed in parallel to the normal synchronous code.

References

  • Futures and Promises
  • Promises and deferred objects in JavaScript…
  • jQuery Deferred Object
  • Angular promises with $q
  • Native JavaScript promises

Hello {{greetingModel}}, with Angular

“One of the best features of Angular is the ability to separate concerns properly into their respective area.”
<div data-ng-app> <!-- bootstrapps angular app on this div --> <h3 data-ng-init="greetingModel = 'World'"> <!-- initializing an object model with value --> Hello {{greetingModel}}, with Angular <!-- curly braces indicating where model will be rendered --> </h3> <fieldset> <input type='text' data-ng-model='greetingModel'/> <!-- binding greetingModel to text input using ng-model --> </fieldset> </div>

This is {{appModel}}

This is {{appModel2}}

“Can have multiple AngularJS apps bootstrapped in one page.” <div data-ng-app="firstApp"> <!-- bootstrapped 'firstApp' onto this div --> <h2 data-ng-init="appModel = 'the first app'"> <!-- initialized appModel object with value 'the first app' --> This is {{appModel}} <!-- printing appModel value --> </h2> </div> <div data-ng-app="secondApp"> <!-- Same thing as firstApp, but separate --> <h2 data-ng-init="appModel = 'the second app'"> This is {{appModel}} </h2> </div> <script> //Modules are setup on the JavaScript side. var firstApp = angular.module('firstApp',[]); var secondApp = angular.module('secondApp'.[]); </script>

Manually Bootstrapping an App

“Sometimes, a manual bootstrap is required. This allows for more control as to when the app will be initialized. ” <div id="my-awesome-app"> <!-- DOM comes first --> <p>{{welcomeMessage}}</p> </div> <script src="http://code.angularjs.org/snapshot/angular.js"></script> <!-- make sure angular library is loaded --> <script> var awesomeApp = angular.module('myAwesomeApp',[]); //create angular app module, called 'myAwesomeApp' awesomeApp.run(['$rootScope', function($rootScope){ //the run function will only be executed once on bootstrapp $rootScope.welcomeMessage = "Greetings! Welcome to my awesome app!!"; }]); //After pre-defining all modules, manual bootstrapping can start angular.element(document).ready(function(){ //In this case, bootstrapping is triggered right after DOM is ready var $element = angular.element('#my-awesome-app'); angular.bootstrap($element, ['myAwesomeApp']); }); </script> Demo

Controllers

  • Facilitate data handling between views and services.
  • Should be used to a minimum.
  • Should not contain any logic, unles it’s UI related.
<script> angular.module('myAwesomeApp',[]) .controller('myAwesomeController', ['$scope', function($scope){ $scope.buttonValue = 'Click Me'; $scope.buttonClicked = function(){ $scope.buttonValue = 'You’ve just clicked me'; }; }]); </script> <div data-ng-controller='myAwesomeController'> <button data-ng-click='buttonClicked()'>{{buttonValue}}</button> </div> Demo

Services

  • To help keep unnecessary logic out of controllers
  • Manage persistent data throughout the app’s lifecycle
  • Make Angular apps more Testable
  • Factory — A singleton object that returns itself
  • Service — Similar to Factory, but instantiated with ‘new’ keyword.
  • Provider — Can also be used in the app.config level of the application as opposed to Factories and Services
  • Value — Simple value based service. Can be updated.
  • Constant — Similar to value, but remains constant. Commonly used for config based values

For more illustrative and detailed examples, visit Tyler’s article.

Custom Directives

  • Useful for manipulating the DOM
  • Four types of custom directives
    • Element, Attribute, CSS Class, & Comment
<!-- Html: Element based custom directive --> <my-custom-directive></my-custom-directive>
<script> <!-- JS --> moduleName.directive('myCustomDirective', function(){ //NOTE: name has to be camel case return { restrict: 'E', //'E' (Element), 'A' (Attribute), replace: true, //removes the custom element name from DOM, template: "<div style='color:blue'>This directive has been generated at: {{time_generated}}</div>" link: function(scope, element, attributes){ var date = new Date(); scope.time_generated = date.getHours() + ":" + date.getMinutes(); } } }); </script>

Filters

“Selects a subset of items from array and returns it as a new array.” — AngularJS Docs

Angular Syntax

{{ expression | filter }}

Example:

… <li data-ng-repeat="item in list | filterNotReady"></li> … <script> moduleName.filter('filterNotReady', function(){ return function(items){ //list to be filtered is passed as first parameter var newList = []; for (var i = 0; i < items.length; i++){ if (items[i].ready === false){ //if item is not ready, add it to the new list newList.push(items[i]); } } return newList; //return new filtered list } }); </script>
